loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a married woman with two children who are enrolled in school. Her husband is a taxi driver who contributes to the provision of family basic needs. She owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

Mwanasiti has operated a retail shop for the past one year; she runs her business from home and her potential clients are her neighbors and friends. She faces a major challenge of transporting her goods to her place of business. She aspires to expand her business. 

With the Kshs 15,000 she wants to purchase rice, wheat flour, maize flour and sugar for her shop. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance to access funds to improve her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase rice, wheat flour, maize flour and sugar for her shop.

loans.name: Estela Josefina

texts.es:
La señora Estela Josefina es casada tiene 45 años de edad, cursó los 6 años de educación primaria, tiene 4 hijos, se dedica a la artesanía, al bordado de blusas, con diferente diseños, inició este trabajo como operaria y tiene 5 años de experiencia.

Solicita un prestamos para la compra de materiales para comprar telas de varios colores e hilos de diferente clases y colores para producir mas blusas, espera mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Sra. Estela Josefina is 45 years old, married, and completed six years of her primary school education. She has four children. Estela is an artisan who makes embroidered blouses in different designs. She started in this line of work as an operator and now has five years of experience.

Estela is requesting a loan to buy materials, such as fabrics in different colors and various types of thread in different colors so that she can produce more blouses. She hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fabrics and thread.

loans.name: Cristo Salva 6 & 7 Group

texts.en:
YoL. is the coordinator of the Cristo Salva Groups 6 & 7. Her family is made up of two children and her long-term partner. Her children are attending school, which has been her most difficult challenge because they are Haitian and they didn't know how to speak Spanish very well. She wants to have her house and a stable business, to save and live a tranquil and safe life.

YoL. is very excited to receive her second loan through Esperanza International. She took her first loan around 7 months ago and she is very grateful for the opportunity her neighbors gave her by inviting her to join the group. Receiving these loans has made possible the investment to her small business. 

YoL. produces candy with traditional preparations. She makes candies from peanuts, coconut and milk. She sells them door-to-door by walking in the streets. She will invest by purchasing milk, sugar, coconut, peanuts, cinnamon, etc.

YoL. dreams of having a beautiful house and a successful business. This group is composed of 10 Haitian immigrants located in the city of La Romana, where tourists and sugarcane are the biggest industries. They all live in a rural area called Batey, surrounded by sugarcane fields.

loans.use: to buy milk, sugar, coconut, peanuts, cinnamon, etc.

loans.name: Lalolagifou

texts.en:
Lalolagifou is a 36-year-old woman living in the town of Foailuga. She is married and has six school-aged children.  

To make a living, Lalolagifou makes and sells cooked food, particularly fried food, in the local community.  Lalolagifou has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 500 WST a month.

In 2011, Lalolagifou joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her business and living situation. Lalolagifou is now requesting a loan of 1,000 WST, which will be used to purchase an oven, large frying pans, pots and a cooler.  This will be the first loan she has taken out from SPBD.  

Lalolagifou plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase an oven, large frying pans, pots and a cooler.

loans.name: Miselemani

texts.en:
Miselemani is a married woman with five children, three of whom attend school while two are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. For the past four years, she has operated a business selling firewood from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition, she sells fish which contributes another source of income. 

With this 20,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase bundles of firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood for resale.

loans.name: Rigoberto

texts.es: Rigoberto, tiene la edad de 45 años, está casado y vive con su esposa y 2 hijos que son su mayor prioridad. El con el crédito pretende comprar los insumos para la asistencia de su cafetal, el tiene pensado comprar los abonos, herbicidas para mejorar  su plantación. El actualmente cuenta con la plantación en condiciones regulares y lo que quiere es asistirla para mejorar su próxima cosecha. El tiene como meta generar el máximo de ganancias vendiendo la cosecha para así tener una mejor calidad de vida y una estabilidad económica de su futuro.Es el primer  préstamo que  recibido de FUDECOSUR. El no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en: Rigoberto, 45 years old, is married and lives with his wife and 2 children who are his top priority.  With the loan, he aims to buy inputs for the care of his coffee.  He plans on buying fertilizers and herbicides to improve planting.  Now, his planting is in fair condition and what he wants is to improve his next harvest.  His goal is to generate maximum profit by selling the crop in order to have a better quality of life and a stable financial future.  This is the first loan he has received from FUDECOSUR.  He has not had any previous loans from state banks, but FUDECOSURE has given him this loan with better facilities and a much lower interest rate.

loans.use: improve his coffee planting.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase another motorcycle.

loans.name: Lidia

texts.es: La señora   Lidia es cliente  nueva será  la primera secuencia de su crédito, la señora Lidia es casada vive en la ciudad de La Paz tiene  dos hijos, la cliente se dedica  a la confección  de chamarras y  también tiene un segundo  negocio  de salón de billar en la misma casa, el préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de telas por  rollo, la cliente trabaja sacrificadamente en su negocio, una ves terminado sus productos los lleva  a la localidad de Desaguadero  que es frontera con Bolivia y Perú,   también  entrega  en  los distintos mercados de la  ciudad de La Paz, donde ya tiene muchos pedidos por la buena calidad en sus prendas de vestir, el dinero del credito lo utilizara en la compra de tela por rollo para confeccionar chamarras,  La Sra. Lidia se encuentra muy agradecida por la oportunidad que le brindan en la otorgación del crédito.
texts.en: Lidia is a new client and this will be the first step in her loan. Lidia is married with two children and lives in the city of La Paz. She makes jackets and also has a second business in the same house which is a billiards room. She will invest the loan in buying fabric by the roll. The client works hard, sacrificing herself for her business. Once the products are finished she brings them to an outlet on the border of Bolivia and Peru. She also delivers them to different markets in the city of La Paz, where she already has a lot of orders because of the good quality of her garments. She will use the money from the loan to buy rolls of fabric to make jackets. Lidia is very grateful for the opportunity they are giving her by granting this loan.

loans.use: to invest in buying rolls of fabric.

loans.name: Metrine

texts.en:
Metrine is an enterprising young woman, smart and creative. She knows how to overcome the problems that life presents and despite having few opportunities for paid work, she has never given up looking for ways to support herself. She started practicing mixed farming 10 years ago. Although she has only farmed for the past ten years, she is working hard and learning good farming practices. Through the profits she makes, she has been able to take care of her family and provide the basic needs for her children. 

Metrine lives near Chepchoina in the Kitale area of Kenya, an area with good weather patterns and favorable weather conditions that support farming. Maize is a very common crop in Kenya and is a staple food for many who regularly eat “ugali,“ or hard porridge cooked from maize. One can usually buy sifted maize flour in the market, but its cost is higher because of the processing. Flour can be less expensive, however, if it is milled directly using a posho mill. The Chepchoina area has only one diesel posho mill that serves a great number of people. The main problem here is that the posho mill keeps breaking down so farmers cannot grind their maize. 

Metrine intends to change this by buying another posho mill to serve the area. She will buy an electric, rather than diesel, posho mill, as they are more reliable. Hopefully breakdowns will be few and far between. To accomplish this, Margaret is applying for a 100,000 KES loan through Juhudi Kilimo to buy a mill. 

Profits derived from the mill will be used to comfortably repay the loan. In the next two years, Metrine sees herself established and running more than one posho mill. She patiently waits for your kindness. Her dream is to build a modern house for her family.

loans.use: To buy an electric posho (cornmeal) mill

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is 25 years, she sells fire wood at Kilifi Kenya. A mother of three who has been in this business for the last two years doing well with the support of her spouse.

This is her second borrowing from VisionFund Kenya after successfully repaying the previous loans successfully. she will use the money to purchase fire wood and charcoal for resale and the anticipated profit to educate her children, she hopes to own a successful business in future.

loans.use: to purchase fire wood and charcoal for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Susan wants to buy fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Dorcas would like to dig a water borehole

loans.name: Rizvan

texts.en: Rizvan G. is a IDP from the Agdam region of Azerbaijan where he worked in agriculture. He came to Beylagan in 1993 and works in the Beylagan city bazaar. He is selling mens clothes in his small booth. He established his business 7 years ago. Rizvan is a client of the Normicro Beylagan Branch since 2003. He has since borrowed 4 more loans from 2004-2006, totaling $1500. Now he needs $1000 to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Celine

texts.en:
S. Celine is 35 years old, married and a mother of six. Her motivation to become a GHAPE member in 2002 stemmed from the difficulty her husband faced in providing for her family's basic needs due to his low salary. Upon becoming a GHAPE member she was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. She obtained loans and was able to raise money to pay school fees for her children and provide them with balanced meals.

Requesting another loan of $600, she now plans to cultivate crops, feed her family with some and sell the rest to raise money for their school needs. She plans to repay the loan in 24 months and the first installment of repayment will be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement

loans.use: purchase seeds, fertilizer, house roof, pay for hired labor

loans.name: Sophy

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Sophy learned to weave from her neighbor in 1980, and then she worked as a weaver for her neighbor. After Mrs. N. got married in 1983, she started her own business weaving silk. She currently owns three looms: one for herself and the other two for her daughters.

Her husband plows land for villagers. They have eight children, 4 sons and 4 daughters.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times already. Now she is asking for a loan of $400. She will use this money to purchase silk materials and sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on her looms.

loans.use: Purchase silk supplies, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Elizabeth Elena

texts.es:
Elizabeth has a strong desire to overcome her situation, and wants to be able to provide her children with a successful future. To this end, she opened a store a year and a half ago. She works in this small shop every day and although she has expanded her inventory, sales have fallen considerably. Elizabeth, does not lose hope and continues to move forward with this business for the welfare of her three beloved children. She feels very motivated and satisfied and holds in her heart all her future plans that are aimed at improving the economic situation of her family. Each day she meets her demanding role as mother and also plays an important part in meeting the finances of her home. She wishes to continue working to acquire a greater number of products to increase profits for the benefit of their children, which are her constant motivation. This is why Elizabeth is applying for a loan to invest in her small shop. Profits generated by sales will increase her children's educational opportunities.

Help Elizabeth and your kindness will be greatly rewarded.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Elizabeth, tiene grandes deseos de superación y quiere obtener para sus hijos un futuro que les otorgue éxitos; así como pieza importante para conseguir sus sueños aperturó una tienda hace un año y medio para formalizar sus ventas y labor ya que antes se dedicaba al comercio de manera ambulante. Con el empeño que ella le otorga día a día a su pequeña tienda está creciendo y aunque las ventas han bajado considerablemente, Elizabeth, no pierde las esperanzas de seguir adelante y continuar con este negocio para bienestar de sus tres queridos hijos. Ella se siente muy motivada y satisfecha y alberga en su corazón planes a futuro que están orientadas a mejorar la situación económica de su familia.Día a día cumple con su exigente rol de madre y también forma parte importante de la economía de su hogar. Desea seguir trabajando para adquirir mayor cantidad de productos y mayores ganancias en beneficio de sus hijos que siempre la motivan a hacerlo, es por ello que Elizabeth solicita un préstamo para invertirlos en su pequeña tienda y con las ganancias que genere la venta de sus productos incrementar el nivel educativo de sus hijos.Apoya a Elizabeth, tu bondad será recompensada grandemente.

loans.use: To purchase essential goods to supply at competative prices within her region.  (Incremento de capital para adquirir mayor cantidad de artículos de primera necesidad a fin de ofertarlos a un precio competente) dentro de su localidad.

loans.name: Ernesta

texts.en:
Ernesta is an elderly widow, mother of eleven adult children, seven of them girls. Ernesta runs a unique business which in its own way, reflects her patient character: she makes and sells ropes.

Ernesta’s ropes are very famous in her community for their durability. She says the most important thing is not to focus on preparing a lot of ropes, but on making sure that they will be useful to the customers. She also says business is very profitable. She travels outsiD. her community to purchase a small truck full of thread with which she makes the ropes. People in her community use the ropes for various purposes.

She is requesting a loan to buy a large quantity of thread so that she can produce more ropes to sell during the holidays. Additional income will help Ernesta maintain a comfortable lifestyle.

loans.use: To get a sufficient amount of thread to continue her rope-selling business.

loans.name: Kapemba's Nguvu Moja Group

texts.en:
Kapemba, age 29, is a widow and takes care of her 2 children (ages 7 and 9). She owns a beauty salon, which she started in 2005. She works there from 6am to 8pm daily and now makes a monthly profit of about $70 from her business.

In the past she took out a successful loan and now would like another to help her business. She will share this with her subgroup member Mosi who owns a shop.

loans.use: To expand the salon's services

loans.name: Kadiba South D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Esther B.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase more cloth material and fabrics. Esther is 40 years old and is married. Her husband has a maize milling business. She has 1 school going son. Each week, Esther makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct better business premises. Esther has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Esther is joined in her small group by Faridah N., Hanifah W. and Suzan K.. Faridah N. has a business in tailoring and wants to buy a sewing machine. Hanifah W. is currently operating a business selling new clothes and wants a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Suzan K. operates a beauty parlor business and wants to buy more cosmetics.

loans.use: To add to tailoring business and expand it

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey P., 41, works selling palm juice in her village. On average, she earns around $7 a day of income. Her husband supplements the household income by working collecting palm juice. After collecting, he hands in the palm juice to his wife for selling. They have three children, two of whom work in the garment sector with salaries of $80 each a month, and one who is a student.

To install (repair) their leaking roof, which is very difficult in the raining season, they are now requesting a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: She will use this loan to fix the leaking roof.

loans.name: Rabih

texts.en: Rabih is 31 years old.  He has 2 children.  He works and lives with his family in Tyre, Southern Lebanon.  Rabih is a blacksmith. This is the first time he has applied for a loan through Al Majmoua. He plans to use this loan to buy equipment to keep his business going.

loans.use: to buy materials

loans.name: Ahmirza

texts.en: U. Ahmirza has been in the livestock business for 40 years.  He has the special skills because he watched and helped his farther in the livestock trade growing up. He has a good flock (the pedigree bull and the milk cow).  The business is only part-time because he also works in a collective farm. Mr. U. Ahmirza  has a good reputation. He is a very good family man and  loves his family and wants a good future for them. He has 5 children. Now Mr. U. Ahmirza applies to KIVA for a business development loan of $625 for 8 months for purchase rams and sheep. He thanks KIVA for the support that KIVA presents to the small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase rams and sheep.

loans.name: Eva

texts.es:
Eva began her business because she needed to help her husband with the monthly expenses and the support of the children. Five years ago, she opened a small general store at the entrance to her house, adding a plastic roof, and little by little stocking the store, eventually she put up a concrete roof for more comfort and security.

She is requesting a loan, which she will repay in 6 months, to stock more merchandise as she is running low. She also needs to purchase more seasonal goods, as people buy a lot of cold drinks, ice and other things to help with the heat of summer. With your support she will be able to continue to grow her business.

Eva inició el negocio ya que tenia la necesidad de ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa ya que a el le pagaban cada 15 dias y por los niños necesitaba dinero antes y no tenian por lo que vieron la posibilidad de abrir un negocio ya que a este puede generar ganancias diario y asi poder cubrir los gastos que iban saliendo todos los dias. Comenzó con la tienda de abarraotes hace 5 años le ha funcionado, desde aquel entonces adapto la entrada de su casa con techo de lamina y alli instalo la tienda, despues poco a poco fue surtiendo mas al negocio y ahora ya le puse el techo de concreto para mayor comodidad y seguridad.

Sin embargo, ella necesita un prestamo por US $500 que pagara en 6 meses par suritr de mercancia la tiendita ya que se le acabo y casi no tiene nada, ademas de que necesita surtir con mercancia de temporada porque la gente compra mucho refresco, hielo y cosas para mitigar el calor. Con tu apoyo Eva podra consolidar su negocio.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO STOCK HER SMALL GENERAL STORE AND PURCHASE SEASONAL GOODS FOR THE SUMMER.

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es:
Maritza is a member of the "Lilies II" Communal Bank, located at Jr. 3 de Octubre / Jr. Contamana, in the YarinaCocha District of the Ucayali area. She is 34 and single. With the first loan she received through Kiva partner Manuela Ramos in the amount of S/. 300, Martiza invested in a business selling treats/snacks.

Maritza runs her business very carefully as it represents her only source of income. The proceeds of her business are also helping her pay for her advanced studies.

The loan currently requested is in the amount of S/. 1,500 and is to be repaid in 5 months. With this loan, she will buy snacks, sodas and essential groceries.

Maritza is happy to receive an endorsement by Manuela Ramos that has not been extended to her by any other institution; no other institution has has had confidence in her or counted on the products guaranteed by their loans, but Manuela Ramos did.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Maritza pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Azucenas II, ubicado en el Jr. 3 de Octubre / Jr. Contamana, D. Distrito de YarinaCocha D. Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 34 años y es soltera. Maritza con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decidió invertir en venta de golosinas.

Maritza atiende su negocio con mucho cuidado y esmero dado que por el momento es su único ingreso. También esta costeando sus estudios superiores.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500 el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará golosinas, gaseosas y abarrotes (alimentos de primera necesidad).

Maritza esta feliz porque se siente respaldada por Manuela Ramos y ninguna otra institución ha confiado en ella dado que no cuenta con bienes que garantice sus prestamos, pero Manuela si lo hizo.

loans.use:
Purchase of treats and general grocery items
Compra de golosinas y artículos en general (abarrotes)

loans.name: Yasmeen

texts.en: Yasmeen baji is the wife of  Mr. Munir who has a burning stove where he makes bread for his customers. He has been in this profession for the last 10 years. Yasmeen is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She has been living in the city of Lahore for the last 17 years. She owns a two story house and rents out the first floor. Yasmeen is the mother of  seven children: five sons and two daughters. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. She has successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a Pakistan microfinance institute). Now Yasmeen is applying for a loan to make another burning stove to increase the profits of her husband's business.

loans.use: To make another burning stove

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah E. has sold firewood at Elmina since 1993. Hannah has received no formal education. She is married and has 2 children. Her husband is a fisherman. She is responsible for feeding the family, paying utility bills, and paying the children's school fees. She plans to use the loan to purchase more firewood to sell. She hopes to use the increased profits to reinvest and expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Aylin Del Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Aylin pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Galácticas 2”, ubicado en el Jr.16 de Noviembre Nº.161 - AA.HH “Las Américas”, del Distrito de Callería del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 32 años y es madre de 1 hijo menor de edad que aun depende de ella, es soltera. Aylin con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.300 decide invertir en la venta de ropas y joyas. Tiene 2 años trabajando con el Banco Comunal. 

En la actualidad  cuenta con el negocio de producto de belleza venta de “UNIQUE y NATURA”, en las mañanas apoya a su pequeño hijo y en las tardes reparte sus pedidos a sus clientes.
 
Con el préstamo de S/.1,800 el cual será pagado en 4 meses invertirá comprando  productos cosméticos de UNIQUE y NATURA. 

Aylin està  contenta porque ha logrado grandes cosas con la ayuda que le brinda el Movimiento Manuela Ramos.
texts.en:
Ms. Aylin is a member of the “Mujeres Galácticas 2” (Galactic Women 2) microfinance institute, located on Jr. 16 in Noviembre Nº.161 - AA.HH "Las Américas,” in the Callería district of the Ucayali department. She is a 32-year-old single mother of an underage son who is still her dependant. Aylin invested her first 300.00 PEN loan from Manuela Ramos in clothing and jewelry sales. She has been working with this microfinance institute for two years.

She currently has a “UNIQUE y NATURA" beauty product business. In the morning, she helps her young son, and in the evening, she distributes her customers’ orders.

With this 1,800.00 PEN loan, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will purchase UNIQUE y NATURA cosmetics.

Aylin is happy because she has managed to do great things with the support that the Manuela Ramos movement has given her.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty products

loans.name: Makhsudakhon

texts.en: Makhsudakhon U. is a 60-year-old woman. She is a widow and has two adult children. She has survived despite difficult circumstances thanks to her optimism, and she strives above all to care for her children. Makhsudakhon is a teacher, but when her husband passed away she decided to run her own business so as to be able to cover all the expenses of her family. She rented a small store on the main street of her neighborhood and stocked it with kitchen inventory. She started out 10 years ago with only $20 in capital. Gradually she expanded her business, and currently she has about $5,000 in capital. Now Makhsudakhon feels that with more working capital the shop could generate more income, so she is asking for a loan of 2000 Somoni ($600) to jump-start the business and raise the family's standard of living. She promises to repay the loan within 6 months.

loans.use: To increase inventory in her kitchen store

loans.name: Suzzy

texts.en:
Suzzy O. is 42 years old and is married with five children. Suzzy sells drinks and provisions. She is able to support her family from the small profits she makes from the business.

Suzzy hopes to expand her business, and needs a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more drinks and provisions to sell. She would like to thank everyone that has made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and provisions to sell

loans.name: Soren

texts.en:
Mrs. Soren C. lives in Trapaing Pour Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is 28 years old and is the mother of a young child. Her husband, Mr. Krouch Nat, is a construction worker. 

Mrs. Soren C. sells bamboo for a living. Aside from this business, she is also a rice middleman who buys rice to keep in stock and re-sell later at better price. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it.  Therefore, she is asking for a loan to buy more rice. She hopes to increase income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy more rice to re-sell

loans.name: On

texts.en: Mrs. On Y. is a villager in Phnum Touch village, Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Chea Bo, is a fisherman who can catch few fish because he does not have enough fishing equipment. In order to catch more fish, Mrs. On Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fishnets for her husband's business. She is 48 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others attend the local school. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy fishnets.

loans.name: Iman

texts.en:
Iman A. is a 47 year old farmer, not only devoted to his work but also to being the father of a family consisting of his wife, 3 children and elderly parents. 

He works hard in the raising of cattle, which he has taken out to graze in the early mornings since his young age.  Without a doubt, it is not an easy task, but the love for his family gives his work reason and meaning. 

Currently, Ilham wants to improve his situation by increasing the number of his cattle, which, in the long run, will provide better financial income.  For this purpose, he applied for $1200 to purchase two calves.  If you support him, he will be forever grateful.

loans.use: Purchase two calves

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary S. has been trading in the local market of Bekwai zongo community in the Ashanti region of Ghana, where she stays with her family. She is 43 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a trader, and two of her children are still in school. She is a busy petty trader who sells tomatoes and other foodstuffs like beans, onions, pepper, carrots, green pepper and salad leaves in the zongo community. She strives very hard to make ends meet for her family.

She does not have sufficient working capital to run the business, which retards her business progress. With the loan, she wants to inject more working capital into the business to purchase good quality stock to upgrade her inventory and revive the business. Mary belongs to a village bank called “Bamali Allah” which means ‘It is only God who can do it’. She hopes to receive GH¢700 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase increased stock of palm oil, tin tomatoes, corn dough, onions, beans, dried fish, etc.

loans.name: Olga María

texts.es:
A la edad de 27 años, la joven Olga M. se dedica a laborar en su negocio de venta de bisuterías como lo son colas, peines, peinetas, espejos de mano, entre otros. Estos productos son ofrecidos por ella misma en su establecimiento en el mercado central de la ciudad de León.

Hoy en día ella ha solicitado un crédito en Ceprodel para la compra de la mercadería. Espera muy confiadamente que su crédito sea otorgado para mejorar las condiciones de su negocio y adquirir a lo inmediato la mercadería.
texts.en:
At the age of 27, the young Olga Martinez is dedicated to work in her business of selling costume jewelry, pony tails, combs, clips, and hand mirrors as well as many other things. These products are offered by her in her establishment in the central market in the city of Leon.

She is asking for a loan from Ceprodel so that she will be able to buy merchandise. She is waiting very confidently to be given the loan because she know it will better the conditions of her business and help her to acquire new merchandise immediately.

(Translated by Alexis of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy Costume Jewelry

loans.name: Dela Paz

texts.en: Dela Paz S., 53 years old, is married and a mother of 5. She lives in Purok 9B, Kiwalan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte in the Southern Philippines. She buys and sells green bananas. She started the business with her own money and was able to sustain the business for a year. Due to the increasing demand in the marketplace, she wants to apply for a loan from HSPFI (a Kiva Partner) amounting to 4,000 Phillipine Pesos to purchase more bananas for delivery. This will be her first loan.

loans.use: To purchase green bananas for resale

location.town: Purok 9B, Kiwalan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Swalia C Siam Habibu Group

texts.en: Mrs. S. Habibu Leila is 28-years of age, married with 3 kids (all of them girls and all in school) and she takes care of eight dependants. She has been in her business for over six years but, at times, cassava can be out of stock. She will use the loan to purchase bags of cassava flour to sell. Her dream is to construct a residential house and rental houses.

loans.use: To purchase bags of cassava flour to sell

loans.name: Cinthya

texts.es: Cinthya es una joven de 23 años que trabaja con la finalidad de ayudar a sus padres, quienes son su mayor tesoro, para ella, vivir con ellos es una bendición. Entablar rápidamente amistad con personas le ayudó a dedicar sus tiempos libres en realizar actividades productivas como brindar servicios de llamadas telefónicas en su localidad, negocio  que viene desarrollando hace 2 años a lado de unas amigas. Lo difícil de esta actividad es el riesgo de sufrir asaltos, pues dispone de varios celulares por la cantidad de personas que solicitan sus servicios y para evitar peligros trata de ser muy prudente. Con las ganancias que obtiene puede pagar sus estudios, y durante sus horas de clase, su padre cubre su puesto de trabajo para no perder clientes. Su deseo a futuro, es asociarse con su padre para instalar un centro de llamadas y venta de teléfonos en el centro de su ciudad. Con los 1000 soles que solicita comprará algunos celulares para mejorar e incrementar la prestación de sus servicios.
texts.en:
Cinthya is a young woman who is 23 years old and works to help out her parents, who are her greatest treasure. For her, living with them is a blessing. Her ability to make friends quickly has helped her to use her free time to do productive activities like set up a phone call service in her town, a business that she has been developing for 2 years with some friends. The difficult part of this work is the risk of muggings, as she has a number of cell phones due to the volume of customers who request her services. She tries to avoid danger by being very careful. With the profits she earns she is able to pay for her studies, and while she is in class, her father takes over the business so as to not lose customers. Her hope for the future is to partner with her father to install a call center and sell telephones in the center of the city. With the 1000 soles that she is requesting, she will purchase a few new cell phones to improve and grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cell phones

loans.name: Otuchopi 2 Asemo Ruth Group

texts.en:
A. Ruth is 45 years old and is widowed with seven children, all schooling. She also looks after three dependents and they are schooling, too.

A. Ruth has been in the business of making local brew for over 20 years which has supported her in educating her children. She is using the loan to purchase sorghum, millet and yeast for making more local brew. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to work very hard and invest in other sectors besides her current business.

loans.use: To purchase sorghum, millet and yeast for making local brew

loans.name: Adjéoda

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur exerce dans la menuiserie, il a ouvert son atelier en 2004, outre les commandes qu’il reçoit de ses clients, il fabrique lui-même des meubles et des lits qu’il expose pour attirer le regard des passants. Il exerce son activité à proximité d’un carrefour. Son stock de planches et des matières nécessaires à son activité étant épuisé, il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter des Bois grumes, 10 planches et divers autres matériaux.
Etant marié et père d’un enfant, c’est avec le revenu de son activité qu’il subvient aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This gentleman works as a carpenter and opened his workshop in 2004. Apart from the orders he receives from customers, he makes and displays his own furniture and beds to catch the attention of passers-by. His business is located by an intersection.
Given that he is out of wooden planks and materials necessary for his work, he is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase wooden logs, 10 wooden planks and various other materials.
Married and the father of one child, he provides for his family with his business revenue.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wood, wooden planks and accessories

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:
H. Nguyễn Thị (130320063) is a 63-year-old woman living in the town of Hưng Nguyên. She is married and has six adult children.

H. owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over twenty years and earns approximately 5,000,000 VND a month.

In 2001, H. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell.

H. is now requesting a new loan of 12,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. The loan will be her 7th from TYM Fund. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Malfada

texts.pt:
Malfada S. S. is 45 years old and is a native of Gaza province. Malfada moved from Gaza province to the city of Matola during the civil war as her husband was looking for work. Malfada works in the Boane market selling a wide range of products. Her best selling products are pans and used clothing. She is able to buy pans for MT 1800 and sell them for MT 2530 and is able to buy a bundle of used clothes for MT 87.50 and sell them for MT 150. She has been in business for the last 15 years.

Malfada is requesting this loan to purchase more products for her store. In recent years she has felt pressure from competitors as the market for her products has become saturated. With her monthly salary Malfada is able to save around MT 500 with a group of 12 other people. In the future she would like to build a home and continue to send her children to school.

Malfada is the mother of three children between the ages of 12 and 15. She is a widow. Malfada studied through the 9th grade at which point she was forced to stop due to her first pregnancy. This will be Malfada's first loan with Hluvuku.

About housing in Mozambique: In rural Mozambique many people still do not live in proper homes. Years of civil war and economic shocks have inhibited residents from accessing capital and buying building materials for their homes. The last several years have been relatively prosperous and many residents are using microfinance as a means to commence construction of their home.
texts.en:
Malfada S. S. is 45 years old and is a native of Gaza province. Malfada moved from Gaza province to the city of Matola during the civil war as her husband was looking for work. Malfada works in the Boane market selling a wide range of products. Her best selling products are pans and used clothing. She is able to buy pans for MT 1800 and sell them for MT 2530 and is able to buy a bundle of used clothes for MT 87.50 and sell them for MT 150. She has been in business for the last 15 years. Malfada is requesting this loan to purchase more products for her store. In recent years she has felt pressure from competitors as the market for her products has become saturated. With her monthly salary Malfada is able to save around MT 500 with a group of 12 other people. In the future she would like to build a home and continue to send her children to school. Malfada is the mother of three children between the ages of 12 and 15. She is a widow. Malfada studied through the 9th grade at which point she was forced to stop due to her first pregnancy. This will be Malfada's first loan with Hluvuku. About housing in Mozambique: In rural Mozambique many people still do not live in proper homes. Years of civil war and economic shocks have inhibited residents from accessing capital and buying building materials for their homes. The last several years have been relatively prosperous and many residents are using microfinance as a means to commence construction of their home.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing Retail Inventory

loans.name: Lambake

texts.en: Lambake sells provision and started this business a year ago, she joined LAPO two years ago. Lambake is 35 years old and married with three children whom she said are their priority as couples, whatever the husband provides she add from her profit to make sure the family feeds, cloth, pay house rent and look after aged parents. The family is based in Lagos. Lambake hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more provision to sell and also meet the demands of customer’s continuously. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more provision to sell

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina is a member of the Kidumu borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 32 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 10 and 7 years old.

Madina has owned a business selling crops for 4 years. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 70,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Madina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania. She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more crops like maize,beans.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Madina hopes to pay school fees, get more food for family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more crops like Maize, Beans

loans.name: Hadijah

texts.en: N. Hadijah is a business woman of forty-one years old. She deals with buying old spare parts that is to say aluminum, wires and other metallic bar and selling them to factory for recycling. She has been doing this business for over six years. She has two children. She is using the loan to add more capital in the business as in purchasing old spare parts that is to say aluminum, wires and other metallic bars. She wants to expand the business to a large scale.

loans.use: To add more capital in the business as in purchasing old spare parts that is to say aluminum, wires and other metallic bars and sell to factory for recycling.

loans.name: Mehnaz Hamidi Group

texts.en:
Mehnaz is the group leader of Mehnaz Hamidi group. There are four members in this group all of them would like to progress their businesses, so they all have requested a group loan of 40000 Afghani. Mehnaz wants to take a loan for his brother’s tire repair shop. Mari wants to take a loan for his son who sells second hand clothes. Roya wants to take a loan for his brother’s fruit cart. Momtaz wants to receive a loan for his husband’s fruit shop. They both have share business. Momtaz cleans and packages the fruits and her husband sells in the shop.  
They are all very thankful to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: progressing their businesses

loans.name: Saidi

texts.en:
Saidi is 38 years old and married with six children with ages ranging from 4 to 13. He and his wife also care for eight dependents from other families. They both work very hard in their general store selling every day from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. and making a modest 70,000 RWF in net monthly profit.

Saidi and his wife hope this loan will help them to buy more products for sale at better prices for their current clients and will hopefully attract new clients as well.

This is not a large loan, relatively speaking, at 200,000 RWF but could make a big difference in the quality of offerings that Saidi and his wife are able to provide to their valued client base. Building the business is building their future security and that of their children and dependents.

Saidi and his wife are very grateful to Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders for the support of their shop. They say “murakoze!” which is Kinyarwandan for "thank you".

loans.use: To buy new products for their store

loans.name: Muruvvat

texts.en:
Muruvvat E. is 55 years old and married with 2 children. He opened his grocery 20 years ago. Muruvvat provides his neighbors and occasional clients with products like bread, rice, sugar, meat, milk, and other items. His wife actively helps Muruvvat run his business. Muruvvat is also working as a tea-room worker and in the evenings his wife works instead of him. With the help of his wife he has been able to move forward with the business.

Muruvvat wants this loan to purchase more merchandise, such as tinned products, sweets, drinks, etc. He and his family appreciate your support in helping him improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Mutia

texts.en:
Mutia P. M. is a 37-year-old woman living in the town of Siutu Salailua. She is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Mutia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Mutia has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 420 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Mutia joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mutia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Mutia is now requesting a new loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Mutia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie N. is from the city of Linao Norte Tuguegarao. She is 55 years old. Rosalie is married and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, Rosalie operates a family member's business providing repair services to local community members. Rosalie has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Rosalie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Rosalie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Sidratu D

texts.en:
Sidratu B. is a merchant who is married to a teacher. She has three children, one in university, one in senior secondary school and the other just finished high school. She has two dependents staying with her.
For about five years now, Sidratu has been in business.  She is now seeking a loan in order to buy more stock for her business and thereafter use the proceeds to provide for her children's schooling needs. Her business is located in a strategic location in the center part of town.

loans.use: To buy drinks and provisions

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa S. is married and has four children. She has received senior high education. Her husband is a contractor.

Theresa sells raw but fresh groundnuts (peanuts) at Ataabazi, which she has been doing since 2004. She uses her income to pay utility bills.

Theresa will use the loan to purchase more groundnuts in large quantities to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to reinvest in the business as she wishes to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To purchase more groundnuts in large quantities to sell

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is a 26-year-old single businesswoman. Francoise lives in Kayonza, a region of Rwamagana in the Eastern Province of Rwanda. She has been in the butchering business for 2 years. She employs two people from her community. Her business working hours are from 8:00 AM until late in the afternoon hours every day.

As her meat business keeps growing, Francoise get more customers every day, so that one cow per day is not enough. Francoise is requesting a Kiva loan through Vision Finance Company. With this loan, she will also buy a refrigerator, which will allow her to keep the meats that she sells to her customers fresher. If this plan is successful, Francoise expects to gain more profits and reinvest them in the other businesses as well as building a secure future for herself.

loans.use: To buy one more cow to get meat to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine E. has been a member of ASHI for three years. She has had an opportunity through ASHI to find friends and confidants with her 5 women loan group.  The bond that hhas held them together, throughout their years in ASHI was established during their training and was strengthen even more by the problems they have encountered along their way. She is given guidance and support to the group due to the many challenges brought about by poverty. 

Josephine has been very busy building her small fish selling business which she put up using the loans she received through ASHI. She finds it interesting and exciting to attend and meet with her group at their weekly center meeting. Through ASHI and her co members, she has been able to gain the confidence to communicate with people. She applies her daily business, house to house, selling her fish all over their village and in the neighboring villages. Josephine feels exhausted upon arriving home at the end of the day after walking and hawking “fish, fish… who wants to buy fish?!”  But, after  seeing her family happy, especially her children, she feels relieved when they have food to eat and savings for their education, all earned out of her income. Josephine is requesting a larger loan to further increase her business and with the profit be able to sustain the education of her youngest 18 year old child through college.

loans.use: Will be used to purchase a large volume of fish to sell

loans.name: Catalino

texts.es:
En el municipio de Somotillo, comarca jícaro bonito el señor Catalino M. Betanco, se dedica a la crianza de ganado bobino, porcino y Aviar, también establece cultivos como maíz, frijol blanco y sorgo los que brindan lo necesario para el sostén familiar.
El señor Catalino M. ha empleado la mayor parte de su vida realizando estas actividades, las desarrolla de 6 a 2 de la tarde todos los días de su vida, ya que al realizarlas provee lo necesario para la mantención de sus 5 hijos.
El crédito será empleado en la compra de dos vacas paridas las que ayudaran a aumentar el hato ganadero y aumentaran sus ingresos beneficiando su desarrollo económico.
texts.en:
Catalino M. B.raises cattle, pigs and fowl in Somotillo, Jícaro Bonito. He also farms corn, white beans and sorghum. These activities produce enough to support his family. Catalino M. has spent most of his life in these activities. He works from 6am until 2pm every day of his life because the work provides for the support of his 5 children. He will use the loan to buy two dairy cows to increase the size of his cattle herd and increase his income which will benefit his economic development.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two dairy cows

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed K. is an approximately 53-year-old man who lives in Makeni city in northern Sierra Leone with his wife and their 5 children. Mohamed has been a businessman for many years now. He sells local produce like rice, ground-nuts, and beans. 

Mohamed has requested a loan of SLL 3,000,000 from Kiva field partner Salone Micro Finance Trust (SMT) in order to expand his business. He will use the loan to buy bags of rice, ground-nuts, and beans to add to his current stock. In this way, his business will improve both in size and quality, making sales and profit-to-sales-margin improve for him.

loans.use: Buy bags of rice, ground-nuts, and beans

loans.name: Asi

texts.en: Asi Y. sells fresh peppers at the Jukwa market. She is divorced and has three children. She is responsible for the general welfare of her children. Her loan will be used to buy more fresh peppers to resell and to process into powder for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her expanded business to save to further her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy more fresh peppers to resell and to process into powder for sale

loans.name: Focused Group

texts.en: Theo M. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Focused Group. He is 27 years old, is single with a 2-year-old child and also cares for a sibling. He is presently a college student and also involved in business. In the photo, Theo is the one holding the sign. For two years Theo has been selling cosmetics such as soap and body spray at the Police Academy Junction in Paynesville, Liberia. He gives his customers a discount when they comes to buy which makes them keep returning. Theo started selling with 10,000 Liberian dollars but now has more than 24,000 Liberian dollars as working capital. He faces problems with the change in prices of goods on the market and the slowdown of sales. Theo plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000.00 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more soaps, body sprays and deodorants to sell. His goal is to grow his business to a shop and live a better life along with his family. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more soaps, body sprays and deodorants to sell

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en: 53-year-old Pacita has a hog raising business.  She started her business in 2008.  Her business is located in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato.  She joined  Community Economic Ventures, Inc. this year, 2010, in order to finance her business while paying low interest.  Now she would like to request a loan of PHP 6,000 to buy more pigs and feed for her piggery business.

loans.use: pigs and feed

loans.name: Gloria Sabina

texts.es:
La  señora Gloria C. es socia del banco comunal Luz y Vida ubicado  en la comunidad El  Aguacate en el  sector  Monay en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad se encuentra  ubicada en el centro sur del país a 2.550 metros de altura sobre el nivel del mar, tiene muchos atractivos turísticos como los cuatro ríos que bañan la urbe, la arquitectura de su centro histórico y los templos donde encontramos detalles en mármol y oro.

Nuestra socia tiene 25 años de edad, es casada y madre de cuatro hijos  que se encuentran de 9, 8, 6, y 5 años, todos sus hijos se encuentran en la escuela de la localidad, su esposo trabaja en su propio taller de mecánica y  gracias al esfuerzo conyugal han logrado construir su propia casa.

Gloria tiene un almacén de venta de productos eléctricos junto a la empresa eléctrica, labora hace cinco años atendiendo de  8 a.m. a 6 p.m. gracias al apoyo del banco comunal del que es socia hace ocho ciclos ha logarado sacar adelante su negocio ahora con  el  nuevo comprará alambre, toma corrientes, interruptores, boquillas y más artículos eléctricos para abaster su local con todo lo necesario.

Su meta comenzar sus estudios en el colegio y obtener su título de bachiller.
texts.en:
Gloria C., 25, is a member of the “Luz y Vida” (Light & Life) communal bank located in El Aguacate, Monay zone, Cuenca. Cuenca is in the south of the country at 2550 meters above sea level. It has many tourist attractions like the four rivers that bathe the city, its downtown architecture and its churches with fine details in marble and gold. She is married and has four children who are 9, 8, 6, and 5 years of age; all are in the local school. Her husband is a mechanic and has his own shop. Thanks to the couple’s efforts, they have managed to build their own house. Gloria has an electrical supplies store located next to the electric company. She has been in operation for 5 years and is open from 8am to 6pm. Thanks to support from the communal bank she’s been a member of for 8 cycles, she has managed to stay in business. She will use the new loan to buy wire, plugs, switches, bulb holders, etc. to stock her store with everything necessary. Her goal is to go to high school and get a high school diploma.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy electrical supplies.

loans.name: Mujeres Emprendedoras Group

texts.es:
Este grupo  se llama mujeres emprendedoras decidieron ponerle este nombre por que  para ellas el iniciar con un crédito en fundacion realidad fue emprender algo nuevo las siete integrantes son:  Guadalupe vende pollo, Cecilia tiene tienda de abarrotes, Alfonso tiene una herrería, Araceli ella tiene  deposito de refresco, ángel Manuel se dedica al cultivo de maíz, Lorenza ella tiene una bonetería y mercería y por ultimo la Sra. Mayra se dedica al cultivo de maíz todos los integrantes pertenecen a la colonia de la nopalera municipio de Axochiapan  Morelos.

Guadalupe fue la representante del grupo anteriormente, se caso con el Sr. jerónimo Cardoso con el procrearon 4 hijos, ana cecilia Cardoso G. de 32 años, Abiel Cardoso G. de 29 años, Rosalba jazmín Cardoso G. de 25 años y la mas pequeña es dulce Montserrat Cardoso G. de 17 años ella se dedica ala venta de pollo lo vende entero y destazado, vende en su domicilio, nos comenta que le conviene mejor salir a venderlo a domicilio por que lo vende mejor, ella puso este negocio en su localidad  nadie vendía sus vecinos tenían que ir a comprar el pollo hasta el centro y esta algo retirado

Con el crédito Guadalupe comprara mas mercancía para tener surtido su negocio y seguir obteniendo ganancias para tener una mejor calidad de vida y no sufrir carencias.


Guadalupe nos dice que se siente muy contenta de pertenecer al grupo de mujeres emprendedoras y esta muy agradecida con los prestatarios de kiva y fundacion realidad, por apoyarlos con los créditos.
texts.en:
This group, called Mujeres Emprendedoras [Enterprising Women], decided to call themselves that because for them, getting a loan was embarking on something new. The seven members of the group are: Guadalupe, who sells chicken; Cecilia, who owns a grocery store; Alfonso, who is a blacksmith; Araceli, who owns a beverage warehouse; Angel Manuel, who grows corn, Lorenza, who owns a sewing and notions shop, and Mayra, who grows corn. All of the group members live in the Axochiapan Morelos neighborhood. Guadalupe is the group representative. She married Jerónimo Cardoso, and had four children: Ana Cecilia Cardoso G. who is 32, Abiel Cardoso G. who is 29, Rosalba Jazmín Cardoso G. who is 25, and the youngest, Dulce Montserrat Cardoso G. who is 17. She works selling chickens, both whole and in pieces. She sells from her home, because there were no vendors in her neighborhood, and her neighbors had to go buy chicken in the center of town, which was out of the way. With this loan, Guadalupe will buy more merchandise to have a well stocked shop, which will help her make more money in order to have a better quality of life and not suffer shortages. Guadalupe is very happy to belong to the group of enterprising women, and is very grateful to the lenders of Kiva and Fundación Realidad for supporting them with the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Eileen Gessner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of chickens

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy building materials and supplies.

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Mrs. Lucena A. is from the barangay (district) of Malaubang, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years of age and married to Ronilo A.. They were blessed with 7 children, 5 of whom are now adults, with 4 of them already married. Lucena is presently engaged in seaweed ("guso") production and culture and fishing. She also receives support from her husband, who is a fisherman. Lucena has been engaged in this business for 20 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP for every harvest from their guso production and culture.

In September 2009, Lucena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucena, as an active member under the PDP-LP, a microfinance program of PMPC, has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. She is now requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to add capital for her seaweed "guso" culture and production and fishing activities. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Lucena from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her general living conditions, save for future use especially for loan repayments, basic needs, guso culture and production expansion and for possible house repairs.
 
 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her seaweed "guso" culture and production and fishing activities

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala eastern region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children, all of whom are in school.  Rehema has operated a business selling food (matooke) for less than one year. Matooke is a meal consisting of steamed green banana and is one of the national dishes of Uganda. To help expand her business, Rehema is requesting a loan of 150,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda, which she will use to buy more matooke. Rehema hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to expand in her business. In the future, Rehema hopes to see her children study up to university.

Note to lenders:
BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva that funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan.

The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.

Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more matooke for selling

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 36 year old single man from Lebanon. He lives alone. He has 7 years of experience working with mobile phones. He began as an employee in a mobile shop and opened his own store in 2003. With his loan requested of US $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., he will be able to increase his merchandise selection of new mobile phones and purchase prepaid telephone cards to sell. The majority of mobile phone users in Lebanon purchase these prepaid cards; it is less common to have an annual phone contract as is common in many Western countries. He reports that both his income and business productivity will be increased as a result of the loan. In the future, he is looking to further expand his business and increase his capital. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To increase his selection of new mobile phones and purchase prepaid telephone cards to sell.

loans.name: Felicita Hortencia

texts.es: Felicita Hortencia tiene 26 años de edad, ella tiene 1 hijo de 5 años a su cargo. Ella se dedica a la venta y elaboración de tortillas, esta joven es muy emprendedora pues todos los días se levanta temprano a las 5 de la mañana pues hay que moler el maíz y también empezar la elaboración de sus tortillas  la mayoría de sus clientes son sus vecinos, es así que junto a su esposo que se dedica a brindar el servicio de tricitaxi pues juntos le han proporcionado a su vivienda algunas mejoras. Ella solicita este financiamiento para la compra de comal, maíz, leña, bolsas plásticas así mejorara su servicio y tendrá más ganancias.
texts.en:
Felicita Hortencia is 26 years old, she is responsible for a 5-year-old son. For a living she makes and sells tortillas. She is a very entrepreneurial young lady. She gets up at 5:00 in the morning to grind the corn and start making her tortillas as the majority of her customers are neighbors. Her husband offers tricycle taxi service and together they have achieved improvements to their home. She requests this loan to buy a hotplate for cooking, corn, firewood, and plastic bags to improve her business and obtain more profits.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital

loans.name: Cirilo

texts.en:
Cirilo L. is from the village of Pagahan, Initao, Misamis Oriental. He is 47 years old, married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Cirilo owns and operates a business venture in the services sector providing motorela, or habal-habal, services to local community members (a motorela is a motorcycle with an extended seat). Cirilo has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 9,500 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Cirilo joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cirilo is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Gladys Del Rocio

texts.es:
Gladys de 42 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Paraíso de Guayaquil zona caracterizada por sus caminos de tierra y montañas. Tiene una pequeña tienda en la parte delantera de su casa.  

Inicio su tienda porque vio que en el sector donde vive no había tiendas disponibles para las personas. Al principio solo tenia una vitrina y arroz para la venta poco a poco fue surtiendo la tienda. Ahora trabaja desde las 07h00am hasta las 20h00pm todos los días. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar vitrinas y arroz para su negocio. En el futuro quiere tener su casa bien construida y una tienda grande y muy conocida.
texts.en:
Gladys is 42 years old, lives in a Peruvian zone in the Paraíso de Guayaquil (Guayaquil Paradise), known for its terrain and mointains. She has a small store in the front section of her home.

She started her business because in the area she lives in there are no stores for people to go to. In the beginning she only had a display cabinet and rice to sell. Little by little she stocked her store. Now she works from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

With the loan she wants to buy display cabinets and rice for her business. In the future she wants her home to be well built and also have a well known store.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Garza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy display cabinets, rice, and canned goods.

loans.name: Harlen

texts.en:
Harlen R. lives in the village of Maribojoc, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old, married and has three young children. Harlen earns a living by running a general store where she sells items people in her community need and use daily. She has been in this line of work for 21 years, and earns about 20,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Harlen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid 10 previous loans from PMPC and has applied for a new one, for 50,000 PHP, to buy additional items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to put money aside for future emergencies. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Hameeda's Group

texts.en:
Hameeda belongs to Lahore which is Pakistan’s second largest city and famous for its history. She has been living in a 2-room brick house in an area there named Mughalpura with her family for the past 9 years. She is 33 years old and operates her clothes selling business to share the financial burden with her husband. She has good number of customers in her neighborhood and earns good profit by selling them a variety of clothes. 

She is married to L. A. who operates a plant selling business. He operates a nursery (a place to display plants & flowers) from where he offers a variety of flowers and plants to customers. He has been doing this business for over 7 years and has a good knowledge of this business. 

Hameeda is the mother of three daughters and a son. All of them are studying except her son who is only 1 year old. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy a variety of plants and flowers to sell through his nursery. Hameeda is confident that her husband will successfully grow his business after this loan investment.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has responsibly paid her installments and attended every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Hameeda.

loans.use: To buy plants & flowers for a nursery (a place to display plants & flowers)

loans.name: Falilatou

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et à 37 ans. Pour aider au menage, elle fait le commerce de pagnes et bijoux. Elle cumule 20 ans dans cette activité et a eu plusieurs credits qui ont été remboursés. Elle s’approvisione à Lomé et revend à la devanture de sa maison. Le credit demandé sera essentiellement destiné à l’achat de 25 paires de pagnes et un lot de bijoux .
texts.en: This woman is married and is 37 years old. To help her household, she sells pagnes (a type of brightly-printed West African cloth) and jewelry. She has gained 20 years' worth of experience in this business and has obtained and repaid many loans. She gets her supplies in Lomé and re-sells them in front of her house. The loan she is seeking will be used to buy 25 sets of pagnes and one batch of jewelry.

loans.use: To buy pagnes (a type of West African cloth) and jewelry

loans.name: Carlos Jose

texts.es:
Carlos es padre de familia de tres hijos, es un hombre que junto a su esposa trabajan para poder dar lo necesario a su familia.
El trabajo de don Carlos es el servicio de taxi, el cual lo hace día a día recorriendo la capital. Anteriormente se dedicaba al negocio, pero luego le dan el trabajo como cadete. Su esposa labora en un almacén y ambos han logrado mejorar su casa con apoyo de Afodenic quien ha dado financiamientos para hacer las mejoras
Con su crédito anterior logro comprar su inodoro e instalarlo, ahora con este nuevo préstamo comenzara la construcción de un cuarto. En donde comprara: decientas piedras, hierro siete bolsas de cemento, arena entre otros y comenzar la obra.
texts.en:
Carlos is a family man with three children, and he works together with his wife in order to grant bare necessities to their family.
Carlos’ job is to provide taxi services, which he does every day driving around the capital. He previously worked in a shop, but then he has been offered a job as taxi driver. His wife works in a store and, thanks to AFODENIC’s support in granting the funds to make the improvements, they both have succeeded in ameliorating their house.
With his previous loan he was able to buy and install his toilet; whit this new loan he will now begin to build a room. Among other things he will buy two hundred stones, iron, seven sacks of cement and sand in order to start the works.

loans.use: To buy stones, sand, cement and iron to build a room

loans.name: Christelle  Sophalia

texts.fr:
jeune femme de 39 ans,célibataire avec 3 enfants  vendeuse de sacs, cartables, valises, depuis bientôt 5 ans , elle a bénéficie d'un prêt auprès de Hope.A l'octroi de ce prêt elle a renforce son stock en achetant des sacs a main pour hommes et dames ,valises et  cartables et tout ce dont les clients ont besoin et ses ventes se sont élevés de 15.000f a 100.000frs par jour. Son étalage attire les clients , elle a toutes les qualités d'articles.

Elle a rembourse son prêt avec succès et épargne beaucoup d'argent comme jamais elle l'a fait. 

Avec le second prêt elle compte refaire les mêmes choses en achetant en gros certains de ces articles comme les cartables et valises, en faisant des commandes a ceux qui vont en Chine, et tient a arriver au bout de son objectif en vendant mieux et en faisant plus d'épargne.
Tres enthousiaste elle tient aller au bout de ses objectifs en faisant mieux et elle a amélioré les conditions de vie de ses enfants.
texts.en:
A 39-year old woman, single with three children, she has been selling handbags, school bags and luggage for almost five years. She had a loan from Hope before. Thanks to this loan she was able to increase her stock purchasing ladies’ and men’s handbags, luggage and backpacks and all items required by her customers. Her sales grew from 15,000 to 100,000 West African francs per day. Her display attracts customers. She offers items in various price ranges. She has repaid her loan successfully and was able to save more money than ever before.

With this second loan, she plans to do the same: purchase wholesale some of her articles such as schoolbags and luggage bags, placing orders with buyers who travel to China. She is set to pursue her goal to increase her sales volume and grow her savings. Very enthusiastic, she is committed to her goals and does her best to improve life conditions for herself and her children.

loans.use: Purchasing travel bags, school bags, suitcases, and handbags

loans.name: Nakale

texts.en:
Nakale is a married woman with eight children, all of whom attend school.  She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a charcoal sales business, selling from her home to her neighbours and passersby.  Nakale faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business.  She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With 25,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en: Silvia, 38 years old, belongs to the “Solidaridad Cachimayo” cooperative bank, which is located in the Cachimayo district of the province of Chinceros. Silvia is married and has two children aged 7 and 18 years old.  She is a seamstress who works from her home.  She is requesting this loan to purchase more fabric to make more clothes and to invest in the maintenance of her sewing machine.
